owl:Ontology.terms:description: Ontology based on the College of American Pathologists' protocol for examination of specimen from patients with primary non-small cell carcinoma, small cell carcinoma or carcinoid tumor of the lung.
owl:Ontology.terms:title: ontoPathLung

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Multiple primary tumors
owl:Class.rdfs:label: m (multiple primary tumors)

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Recurrent
owl:Class.rdfs:label: r (recurrent)

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Post-treatment
owl:Class.rdfs:label: y (post-treatment)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Additional pathologic findings. Select all that apply.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: additional pathologic findings

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: A very rare condition characterized by generalized proliferation of pulmonary neuroendocrine cells. It manifests as progressive cough and dyspnea. It is considered a precursor for pulmonary carcinoid tumor.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: diffuse neuroendocrine hyperplasia

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Emphysema is defined by abnormal and permanent enlargement of the airspaces that are distal to the terminal bronchioles. This is accompanied by destruction of the airspace walls, without obvious fibrosis (i.e. there is no fibrosis visible to the naked eye). Emphysema can exist in individuals who do not have airflow obstruction; however, it is more common among patients who have moderate or severe airflow obstruction.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: emphysema

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Specify
owl:Class.rdfs:label: inflammation

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Specify
owl:Class.rdfs:label: metaplasia

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: For reporting cancer biomarker testing results, the CAP Lung Biomarker Template should be used. Pending biomarker studies should be listed in the Comments section of this report.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ancillary studies
bronchial margin involved by carcinoma in situ
bronchial margin involved by invasive carcinoma
bronchial margin uninvolved by carcinoma in situ
bronchial margin uninvolved by invasive carcinoma

owl:Class.icd11: 2C25.4 Carcinoid or other malignant neuroendocrine neoplasms of bronchus or lung
owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: A neuroendocrine neoplasm that arises from the lung. It is characterized by the presence of uniform polygonal cells with small or moderate amount of cytoplasm and inconspicuous nucleoli. The cells are usually arranged in organoid and trabecular patterns. It is classified as typical or atypical carcinoid tumor based on the number of mitotic figures and the absence or presence of necrosis. Atypical carcinoid tumors have a worse prognosis.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: carcinoid tumors

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any relevant comment related to the specimen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: comment

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Sign-out date
owl:Class.rdfs:label: date

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: direct invasion of adjacent structures, can be macro or microscopically determined
owl:Class.rdfs:label: direct invasion of adjacent structures

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Specify structures.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: adjacent structures present and involved
adjacent structures present but not involved

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Explain.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: direct invasion of adjacent structures cannot be assessed

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: A tiered grading scheme for lung cancer has been put forth by the AJCC.1 However, its reproducibility and prognostic significance have not been rigorously tested, and therefore histopathologic grade is designated as an optional reporting element. https://documents.cap.org/protocols/cp-thorax-lung-2017-protocol-4003.pdf
owl:Class.rdfs:label: histologic grade

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: For consistency in reporting, the histologic classification published by the World Health Organization (WHO) for tumors of the lung, including carcinoids, is recommended.8 Although acceptable in small biopsies, a designation of non-small cell lung carcinoma, not otherwise specified (NSCLC, NOS), is not acceptable in resection specimens.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: histologic type

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Carcinomas associated with chromosomal rearrangement in the NUT gene are called NUT carcinomas. These are poorly differentiated carcinomas genetically defined by the presence of NUT gene rearrangement.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: NUT carcinoma

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: A carcinoma that arises from the lung and is characterized by the presence of malignant glandular epithelial cells. There is a male predilection with a male to female ratio of 2:1. Usually lung adenocarcinoma is asymptomatic and is identified through screening studies or as an incidental radiologic finding. If clinical symptoms are present they include shortness of breath, cough, hemoptysis, chest pain, and fever. Tobacco smoke is a known risk factor.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: adenocarcinoma

owl:Class.icd11: XH6BU6 Mucinous adenocarcinoma in situ of the lung
owl:Class.rdfs:label: mucinous adenocarcinoma in situ of the lung

owl:Class.icd11: XH1FR9 Non-mucinous adenocarcinoma in situ of the lung
owl:Class.rdfs:label: adenocarcinoma in situ (AIS) nonmucinous

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: A rare usually indolent lung carcinoma characterized by a cribiform and tubular pattern and the presence of glandular epithelial cells. Clinical symptoms include shortness of breath, cough, wheeze, hemopytsis and chest pain.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: adenoid cystic carcinoma

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: An aggressive carcinoma with a poor prognosis characterized by a presence of both malignant squamous cells and glandular cells.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: adenosquamous carcinoma

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: A morphologic variant of lung adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of mucin pools containing islands of well differentiated adenocarcinoma cells.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: colloid adenocarcinoma

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Well-differentiated fetal adenocarcinoma (WDFA) of the lung is a rare, primary, low-grade, bronchopulmonary neoplasm characterized by a well-circumscribed, usually large, pulmonary mass that is histologically composed of glycogen-rich neoplastic glands and tubules that resemble fetal lungs at 10 to 16 weeks of gestation and benign adjacent stroma. It typically presents with chest pain, cough, dyspnea, hemoptysis and/or generalized, non-specific symptoms, such as night sweats, lethargy, poor appetite and weight loss.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: fetal adenocarcinoma

owl:Class.icd11: XH0F68 Acinar adenocarcinoma of the lung
owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: A morphologic variant of lung adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of acinar structures composed of columnar or cuboidal cells. (NCI05)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: invasive adenocarcinoma acinar predominant

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: A morphologic variant of lung adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of papillary structures.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: invasive adenocarcinoma papillary predominant
invasive adenocarcinoma predominant subtype cannot be determined

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: A squamous cell carcinoma characterized by the presence of cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, scant amount of cytoplasm, and peripheral nuclear palisading
owl:Class.rdfs:label: basaloid squamous cell carcinoma

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Squamous cell carcinomas with morphologically prominent production of keratin.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma

owl:Class.icd11: 2C25.3 Large cell carcinoma of bronchus or lung
owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: A malignant epithelial neoplasm composed of large, atypical cells.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: large cell carcinoma

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Minimally invasive adenocarcinoma: adenocarcinoma (≤3 cm in greatest dimension) with a predominantly lepidic pattern and ≤5 mm invasion in greatest dimension.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: minimally invasive mucinous adenocarcinoma

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Minimally invasive adenocarcinoma: adenocarcinoma (≤3 cm in greatest dimension) with a predominantly lepidic pattern and ≤5 mm invasion in greatest dimension.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: minimally invasive nonmucinous adenocarcinoma
invasive adenocarcinoma mixed mucinous and nonmucinous

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: A carcinoma morphologically characterized the presence of cuboidal mucous cells, goblet-like mucous cells, squamoid cells, cystic changes, and a fibrotic stromal formation. It can occur in several anatomic sites, including parotid gland, oral cavity, paranasal sinus, skin, breast, lung, larynx, and lacrimal ducts. It is classified as low or high grade.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: mucoepidermoid carcinoma

owl:Class.icd11: 2C25.4 Carcinoid or other malignant neuroendocrine neoplasms of bronchus or lung
owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: A low, intermediate, or high grade malignant neoplasm with neuroendocrine differentiation that arises from the lung. This category includes typical carcinoid tumor, atypical carcinoid tumor, small cell carcinoma, large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma, and combined carcinoma.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: neuroendocrine tumors
non small cell carcinoma, subtype cannot be determined

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The following tumor types should NOT be reported using this protocol: 1- Mesothelioma (consider the Pleural Mesothelioma protocol) 2- Lymphoma (consider the Hodgkin or non-Hodgkin Lymphoma protocol) 3- Sarcoma (consider the Soft Tissue protocol)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: other histologic type not listed

owl:Class.icd11: 2C25.Y Other specified malignant neoplasms of bronchus or lung
owl:Class.rdfs:label: salivary gland type tumors

owl:Class.icd11: 2C25.Y Other specified malignant neoplasms of bronchus or lung
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sarcomatoid carcinomas

owl:Class.icd11: 2C25.1 Small cell carcinoma of bronchus or lung
owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: A highly aggressive subtype of lung carcinoma characterized by the presence of malignant small cells and necrosis. Metastatic disease is usually present at the time of diagnosis.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: small cell carcinoma

owl:Class.oboInOwl:hasExactSynonym: non-small cell lung squamous cell carcinoma
owl:Class.icd11: 2C25.2 Squamous cell carcinoma of bronchus or lung
owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: A carcinoma arising from malignant squamous bronchial epithelial cells and characterized by the presence of keratinization and/or intercellular bridges. Cigarette smoking and arsenic exposure are strongly associated with squamous cell lung carcinoma.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: squamous cell carcinoma (SqCC)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Based on data showing prognosis correlates with invasive size in nonmucinous adenocarcinomas with lepidic and invasive components, the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) has adopted a rule that for nonmucinous adenocarcinomas with a lepidic component, only the size of the invasive component is used to assign T category.1-4 This rule aligns with the recommendation previously set forth by the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) of using invasive size for T descriptor size.5 This rule does not apply to other histologic types of lung cancer, including invasive mucinous lung adenocarcinoma. https://www.cap.org/protocols-and-guidelines/cancer-reporting-tools/cancer-protocol-templates
owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Invasive Tumor Size (applies only to invasive nonmucinous adenocarcinoma with a lepidic component). https://www.cap.org/protocols-and-guidelines/cancer-reporting-tools/cancer-protocol-templates
owl:Class.rdfs:label: invasive tumor size (only if invasive nonmucinous adenocarcinoma with a lepidic component)

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: The report is 'synoptic', meaning explicitly structured into discrete data concepts rather than narrative text. The present ontology is based on ”Protocol for the Examination of Specimens From Patients With Primary Non-Small Cell Carcinoma, Small Cell Carcinoma, or Carcinoid Tumor ofthe Lung”, version Lung 4.0.0.3. Source: CAP Cancer Protocol Template. https://documents.cap.org/protocols/cp-thorax-lung-2017-protocol-4003.pdf
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cap lung specimen protocol

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Description of all tissue or removed foreign materials received by the surgical pathology laboratory; it also includes vital documentation of the specimen's handling within the laboratory and the tissue's disposition.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: macroscopic description

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Individual margin reporting required if any margins are involved or margin involvement cannot be assessed.
owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Surgical margins represent sites that have either been cut or bluntly dissected by the surgeon to resect the specimen. The presence of tumor at a surgical margin is an important finding, because there is the potential for residual tumor remaining in the patient in the area surrounding a positive margin. Peripheral wedge resections contain a parenchymal margin, which is represented by the tissue at the staple line(s). Lobectomy and pneumonectomy specimens contain bronchial and vascular margins and, depending on the completeness of the interlobar fissures and other anatomic factors, may also contain parenchymal margins in the form of staple lines. En bloc resections that contain extrapulmonary structures as part of the specimen have additional margins (eg, parietal pleura, chest wall), which should be designated by the surgeon for appropriate handling. Note that the visceral pleura is not a surgical margin. https://documents.cap.org/protocols/cp-thorax-lung-2017-protocol-4003.pdf
owl:Class.rdfs:label: margins

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Specify margins examined and distance of the tumor to the closest margin.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: all margins uninvolved by carcinoma

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: other attached tissue margin
owl:Class.rdfs:label: other
other margin involved by invasive carcinoma
other margin uninvolved by invasive carcinoma
parenchimal margin involved by carcinoma in situ
parenchimal margin involved by invasive carcinoma
parenchimal margin involved by lepidic component of invasive carcinoma
parenchimal margin uninvolved by carcinoma in situ
parenchimal margin uninvolved by invasive carcinoma
parenchimal margin uninvolved by lepidic component of invasive carcinoma

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Reporting of pT, pN, and (when applicable) pM categories is based on information available to the pathologist at the time the report is issued. Only the applicable T, N, or M category is required for reporting; their definitions need not be included in the report. The categories (with modifiers when applicable) can be listed on 1 line or more than 1 line.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pTNM (pathologic stage classification)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Descriptors
owl:Class.rdfs:label: descriptors

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: With respect to this protocol, reporting a pM designation (ie, pM1a, pM1b, or pM1c) is required only if metastasis is pathologically confirmed in the specimen(s) being examined. The designation pMX should not be used.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: distant metastasis (pM)

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Distant metastasis absent.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pM0

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Distant metastasis present.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pM1

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Separate tumor nodule(s) in contralateral lobe; tumor with pleural or pericardial nodules or malignant pleural (or pericardial) effusion.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pM1a

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Single extrathoracic metastasis in a single organ (including involvement of a single nonregional lymph node)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pM1b

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: pM1c
owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Multiple extrathoracic metastases in single organ or in multiple organs.
Metastasis in ipsilateral peribronchial and/or ipsilateral hilar lymph nodes, and intrapulmonary nodes, including involvement by direct extension
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pN1

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Metastasis in ipsilateral mediastinal and/or subcarinal lymph node(s)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pN2

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Metastasis in contralateral mediastinal, contralateral hilar, ipsilateral or contralateral scalene, or supraclavicular lymph node(s)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pN3

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pNX

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Tumor ≤3 cm in greatest dimension, surrounded by lung or visceral pleura, without bronchoscopic evidence of invasion more proximal than the lobar bronchus (ie, not in the main bronchus)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pT1

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Tumor ≤1 cm or less in greatest dimension; A superficial spreading tumor of any size whose invasive component limited to the bronchial wall and may extend proximal to the main bronchus also is classified as T1a, but these tumors are uncommon
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pT1a

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Tumor >1 cm, but ≤2 cm in greatest dimension
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pT1b

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Tumor >2 cm but ≤3 cm in greatest dimension
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pT1c

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Minimally invasive adenocarcinoma: adenocarcinoma (≤3 cm in greatest dimension) with a predominantly lepidic pattern and ≤5 mm invasion in greatest dimension.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pT1mi

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: No evidence of primary tumor.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pT0
pT2

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Tumor >5 cm but ≤7 cm in greatest dimension; or directly invading any of the following: parietal pleura (PL3), chest wall (including superior sulcus tumors), phrenic nerve, parietal pericardium; or separate tumor nodule(s) in the same lobe as the primary.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pT3

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Tumor >7 cm in greatest dimension; or tumor of any size invading one or more of the following: diaphragm, mediastinum, heart, great vessels, trachea, recurrent laryngeal nerve, esophagus, vertebral body or carina; or separate tumor nodule(s) in an ipsilateral lobe different from that of the primary.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pT4

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Primary tumor cannot be assessed, or tumor proven by presence of malignant cells in sputum or bronchial washings but not visualized by imaging or bronchoscopy
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pTX

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Squamous cell carcinoma in situ (SCIS) or adenocarcinoma in situ (AIS): adenocarcinoma with pure lepidic pattern, ≤3 cm in greatest dimension.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pTis

owl:Class.oboInOwl:hasExactSynonym: Procedure used to obtain tumor specimen [Type] in Specimen
owl:Class.rdfs:label: procedure

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: "A biopsy is a medical test commonly performed by a surgeon, interventional radiologist, or an interventional cardiologist involving extraction of sample cells or tissues for examination to determine the presence or extent of a disease." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biopsy
owl:Class.rdfs:label: biopsy

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Resection is the removal of all of an internal organ or body part, or a key part (lung lobe; liver quadrant) of such an organ or body part that has its own name or code designation. Excision is the cutting out or removal of only part of an organ, tissue, or other body part from the patient. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surgery#Types_of_surgery
owl:Class.rdfs:label: resection
no lymph nodes submitted or found

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Optional data element.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: additional dimension 1

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Optional data element.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: additional dimension 2

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Tumor size cannot be determined.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cannot be determined

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Greatest measured dimension of tumor (in cm).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: greatest dimension

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: At the present time, STAS should not be incorporated into the measurement of tumor size.
owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: STAS is a recently described concept which is defined as micropapillary clusters, solid nests or single cells of tumor extending beyond the edge of the tumor into the air spaces of the surrounding lung parenchyma. Initial studies have shown that the presence of STAS is associated with an increased incidence of recurrence in tumors that have undergone limited resection (eg, segmentectomy, wedge resection). https://documents.cap.org/protocols/cp-thorax-lung-2017-protocol-4003.pdf
owl:Class.rdfs:label: spread through air apaces (STAS)

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Greatest measured dimension of tumor.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: greatest measure

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Based on data showing prognosis correlates with invasive size in nonmucinous adenocarcinomas with lepidic and invasive components, the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) has adopted a rule that for nonmucinous adenocarcinomas with a lepidic component, only the size of the invasive component is used to assign T category.1-4 This rule aligns with the recommendation previously set forth by the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) of using invasive size for T descriptor size.5 This rule does not apply to other histologic types of lung cancer, including invasive mucinous lung adenocarcinoma. https://www.cap.org/protocols-and-guidelines/cancer-reporting-tools/cancer-protocol-templates
owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Total Tumor Size Inclusive of Invasive and Lepidic Components (applies only to invasive nonmucinous adenocarcinoma with a lepidic component). https://www.cap.org/protocols-and-guidelines/cancer-reporting-tools/cancer-protocol-templates
owl:Class.rdfs:label: total tumor size (only if invasive nonmucinous adenocarcinoma with a lepidic component)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Optional data element.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: additional dimension 1

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Optional data element.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: additional dimension 2
greater than 10 percent residual viable tumor
less than or equal to 10 percent residual viable tumor

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: When more than 1 tumor nodule is identified in resection specimens, it is important to attempt distinction of synchronous primary tumors from a tumor with intrapulmonary metastasis. These scenarios have different prognoses and are staged differently. https://www.cap.org/protocols-and-guidelines/cancer-reporting-tools/cancer-protocol-templates
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tumor focality
multifocal lung adenocarcinoma with lepidic features

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Multiple tumor nodules of different histologic types (eg, 1 squamous cell carcinoma, 1 adenocarcinoma) are considered synchronous primaries and should be recorded as such in the pathology report with an individual TNM assigned to each tumor. https://www.cap.org/protocols-and-guidelines/cancer-reporting-tools/cancer-protocol-templates
owl:Class.rdfs:label: synchronous primary tumors in different lobes

owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Multiple tumor nodules of different histologic types (eg, 1 squamous cell carcinoma, 1 adenocarcinoma) are considered synchronous primaries and should be recorded as such in the pathology report with an individual TNM assigned to each tumor. https://www.cap.org/protocols-and-guidelines/cancer-reporting-tools/cancer-protocol-templates
owl:Class.rdfs:label: synchronous primary tumors in same lobe

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Select all that apply.
owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Anatomical location of tumor.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tumor site

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Applies to histologic types other than invasive nonmucinous adenocarcinoma with a lepidic component.
owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Measurement of tumor size (in cm).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tumor size
visceral pleura invasion cannot be determined

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: intrapulmonary metastases (separate tumor nodules of same histopathologic type)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: separate tumor nodules of same histopathologic type in different lobes

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: intrapulmonary metastases (separate tumor nodules of same histopathologic type)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: separate tumor nodules of same histopathologic type in same lobes
